column1: reallyrealghost 114743538934 "2015-03-27 09:04:59 GMT" https://reallyrealghost.tumblr.com/post/114743538934/my-parents-are-dead-and-my-sister-is-disabled "kanalashesa:congalineofdurin:cockismybusiness:teamâ€”wolverine:therealbarbielifts:eisforedna:On May 28th
column4: turned 31.Â  Her mental age is about three years old. She loves Winnie the Pooh
column6: and Sesame Street. Even though the below picture is unconvincing.Â  Edna and â€œCookie.â€ I think she was trying to play it cool.Â  My name is Jeanie. Iâ€™m Ednaâ€™s younger sister. Iâ€™m also her guardian and caregiver.Â  Thatâ€™s me on the left.Â (Hey
column7: you never know. After a year of writing a blog about online dating -Â Jeanie Does the InternetÂ - Iâ€™ve come to learn that there are A LOT of fools on the internet.)Â  ANYWAY
column8: Iâ€™mÂ not â€œdoing the internetâ€ anymore. Iâ€™m taking care of Edna full-time
column9: after completing my MFA in Writing for Screen & Television at USC. May 16
column10: 2014. I wanted a picture. Edna wanted breakfast. In case youâ€™re wondering where our parents are
column11: theyâ€™re dead. Our mom died of breast cancer when she was just 33.Â  Us with mom before she died. (Obviously.) As for our dad
column12: he peaced-out around the time my mom got sick. His loss - weâ€™re awesome.Â  Here we are being awesome at the beach. Pushing a wheelchair in the sand? Not so awesome.Â  In case youâ€™re wondering â€œWhatâ€™s wrong?â€ with my sister - as a stranger once asked me on the street Â - Â NOTHING. Yes
column13: Edna has a rare form of epilepsy - Lennox-Gastaut syndrome - but I donâ€™t know if thatâ€™s anymore â€œwrongâ€ than people who donâ€™t have manners.Â  Basically
column15: â€ and started having seizures as a baby. They eventually got so bad that they cut off the oxygen to her brain
column16: causing her to be mentally disabled. Or impaired. Or intellectually disabled. Or whatever you want to call it - except â€œretarded
column18: President Obama signed Rosaâ€™s Law into effect
column19: replacing that word with â€œintellectually impaired.â€Â  Which is cool and all
column20: but services for the disabled and the people who care for them are SEVERELY LACKING. Also
column21: thereâ€™s a bunch of people working in taxpayer-funded positions who are supposed to help families like us
column23: I know.) They just fill out paperwork (whenever they feel like it) with asinine statements like this:Â  YUP. I transport my sister down the stairs in her wheelchair
column24: because that is not only safe
column25: but TOTALLY PRACTICAL. Why doesnâ€™t everyone in a wheelchair just take the stairs
column26: for Godâ€™s sake? Stop being so lazy
column29: Ednaâ€™s legs do work. Whether or not she wants them to
column30: is another story.Â  Edna refusing to go inside.Â  These are theÂ stairs that I have to carry her up - by myself - on a daily basis. That is
column31: until one of my legs break and both of us are just sitting at the bottom of the stairs
column33: I have begged - BEGGED - the State of California to help my sister
column34: which they are required by law - The Lanterman Act specifically - to do so. But theyâ€™ve told me â€œthese things take timeâ€ and that I â€œneed to amend my expectations.â€ (That was said to me when I refused to place Edna at AN ALL-MALE CARE FACILITY. Because yes
column35: that was an â€œoptionâ€ that was offered to me.)Â  Prior to Edna moving in with me in my one-bedroom apartment
column36: she was living with her amazing caregiver
column39: where we went to high school and I did my undergrad. Ednaâ€™s reppinâ€™ the Wildcats below.Â  But back in November
column40: Gaby also died from breast cancer. (FUCK YOU
column41: BREAST CANCER!) This picture was taken a month before she died. She never even told me she was sick because she didnâ€™t want me to worry.Â  By the way
column42: we were raised by our grandma. Edna and her were very close. Sheâ€™s dead
column43: too. Surprise. She died when I was 20 and Edna was 21. Thatâ€™s when I became Ednaâ€™s legal guardian and Gaby stepped into the picture to help me out with Edna.Â  So
column47: where I tried to get the folks over at The Frank D. Lanterman Regional Center to help me.Â Iâ€™ve told them Iâ€™m worried about our safety - that one of us could get hurt on theÂ stairs - Â Iâ€™ve told them I canâ€™t afford to pay the private babysitters $15/hour because the ones social services sent me who make $9/hour were unreliable (they didnâ€™t show up on time or at all so I could get to school and work)
column48: untrustworthy (one of them let Edna go to the bathroom in the kitchen and then took her into the bathroom because â€œthat what I thought I was supposed to do.â€)Â  But the people over at the FLRC donâ€™t return my calls
column49: they donâ€™t file the paperwork on time - and the first caseworker that was assigned to us actually LAUGHED AT my sister when he came to our home to evaluate her. When I reported him to his supervisor
column51: â€œThatâ€™s just [insert name of said jackass].â€Â  He was one of the two caseworkers that contributed to the report I mentioned above
column52: which also included this:Â  So let me get this straight - I have to feed
column54: dress and help Edna in the bathroom and you canâ€™t deduce whether or not she is able to vote? What in the fuck?! Now I realize I seem angry. And you can bet your balls I am. Iâ€™m also sad. Sad for those who donâ€™t have family to stick up from them and who waste away God knows where
column55: monitored by no one. OrÂ monitored by people who physically and sexually assault them.Â  Iâ€™m also sadÂ for the caregivers who are SO EXHAUSTED - trying to take care of their loved ones - while also trying to take care of themselves and battling a system that is supposed to help
column56: but does nothing of the sort.Â And I know a lot of people give up. They let their dreams
column58: their friendships slide. All while trying not to resent the very person youâ€™re doing it all for. Edna wanted to sit next to me the other day while I was writing. Clearly
column59: sheâ€™s not impressed.Â  Hereâ€™s the thing: I REFUSE TO GIVE UP. Iâ€™M NOT GIVING UP ON HER OR MYSELF. Iâ€™m going to pursue my dreams while taking care of her
column60: AND while ensuring that the people paid to do their jobs ACTUALLY do them. Thatâ€™s where you come in. I need you to help me get my story out there. Because I know Iâ€™m not alone in this. I want to connect with familiesÂ who are in similar situations and also show people who have no idea what itâ€™s like to care for someone with a disability (or even a loved one who is sick) that it can be rewarding. Super fucking hard. Exhausting. Painful. Isolating. But
column61: rewarding.Â  Iâ€™m going to get help for my sister - and others. My hope is that by sharing our story
column62: I can bring awareness to the lack of services and help for the disabled.Â  Thank you
column63: Â  JeanieÂ  Facebook:Â Â facebook.com/eisforedna Twitter: @EisforEdnaÂ   This made me cry  SIGNAL BOOST   STOP SCROLLING. THIS PERSON ISNâ€™T ASKING FOR MONEY AND THIS POST WONâ€™T MAKE YOU SAD. This is a really uplifting and inspirational story of a family sticking by each other and making things work despite a whole lot of shit They just want to find other people in the same position they are
column64: for a sense of community and to feel like they arenâ€™t alone. I know out of all of you
column65: some of you have followers who are living with and taking care of intellectually or emotionally disabled family members
column66: and this lovely and unbreakable pair of sisters need to find them. SIGNAL BOOOOOOOOOST  Repost! This story needs told!" False link

column2: what are the costs? Why yes
